bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, April 1, 1946

div1.p: Hench informs Kean and Truby about Mabel Lazear's death. He hopes that Kean's health improves.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, April 1, 1946
div1.opener:
Yellow Fever.
April 1, 1946
Generals J. R. Kean and Albert E. Truby
Dear Friends:
div1.p:
I have just heard that Mrs. Lazear died recently. I
don't know the date nor any of the details. I am very sorry, as
I had written her hoping to visit her at the time of the A.M.A.
meeting in San Francisco in July. I will try to get in touch with
her son and daughter. If my information is correct, I am indeed
glad that I saw what little of her I did see. She wasn't very
informative, as you will remember. Nevertheless, I did get some
valuable data from her.

General Kean, I am so hopeful that you are feeling
much better. I expect to be in Washington for four or five days
early in June and certainly will call on you wherever you are, to
pay my respects. Whether or not Mrs. Hench will be with me, I
do not yet know.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
